Now...a word of warning.....the little girl will say something somewhere in the beginning of the movie which may turn you off!  It actually turned me off to the point where I just turned the whole MOVIE off.  However, the next day, I said,  "What the heck...I'll give it another chance."  So I did, and once you get beyond that particular THING (you will know it when you watch the movie), the film will be cute, quirky and watchable.  Is it perfect?  Of course not!  The Adam Arkin character befriending the super young waitress and bringing her home for Christmas?  Okay....weird.  Marissa Tomei and Diane Keaton portrayed as sisters (I believe Marissa is in her fifties and Diane Keaton is in her seventies)....that's a bit unbelievable, as well.  But....so what! Classic Christmas movies have a magic that cant be manufactured, but Love the Coopers desperately tries to do just that. It employs a familiar conceit  dysfunctional family gathers for holiday meal  and enlists recognizable actors to deliver it, but the result plays like a collection of ideas and jokes borrowed from other movies. The film is occasionally amusing but rarely feels genuine.

Diane Keaton and John Goodman are Charlotte and Sam, a long-married couple waiting for their extended family to arrive for the big meal, at which they intend to announce that they're separating. We see the various family members making their way toward the gathering. Theres the son (Ed Helms) with the broken marriage, jobless and adrift. Theres Charlottes sister (Marisa Tomei), who is arrested while trying to shoplift a Christmas present. Theres a grandson (Timothe Chalamet) in the throes of romantic infatuation.

The thread that comes closest to being absorbing is played out by Olivia Wilde and Jake Lacy, whose characters do an opposites-attract dance after meeting at the airport. But the film, written by Steven Rogers and directed by Jessie Nelson, is too obviously manipulative. Its shameless appropriation doesnt help. There is, for instance, a folksy narration straight out of A Christmas Story, which is also raided for its dogs-disrupt-dinner-plans gag.

Love the Coopers wants to be as beloved as that movie and several others that it calls to mind, but its overwrought exchanges (especially between Charlotte and Sam) and efforts to push every emotional button in sight make it tedious, not tenderhearted.

I didn't go into this one expecting much.  The Hallmark Channel saturates the airwaves with trite cookie cutter holiday romances.  The big screen is full of dysfunctional, or worse, profane exercises set during yuletide represented this year by "The Night Before" and "Krampus".  I was expecting "The Family Stone" redux but "Love the Coopers" offered so much more.  The basic setup is the extended Cooper family is in crisis mode.  Dad Sam (John Goodman) and Mom Charlotte (Diane Keaton) are ready to throw in the towel after forty years of less than wedded bliss but are going to pull out all the stops for one last memorable Christmas.  Son Hank (Ed Helms)  in the throes of a recent divorce and loss of employment is determined to get presents for his kids.  Daughter Eleanor (Olivia Wilde) is currently in a romantic entanglement with a married man and is cynical about ever being in a meaningful relationship.  Most poignant of all is Grandpa Bucky (Alan Arkin) has a platonic friendship with a sweet young waitress Ruby (Amanda Seyfried) who is mulling going to the West Coast.  This film is a lot like life in that not all predicaments are magically resolved but epiphany is possible.  Director Jessie Nelson has a flavorful approach to the material which serves screenwriter Steven Rogers humanistic narrative to a tee.  There isn't a false note or a bad performance in the bunch.  I'd also like to note a terrific performance by Jake Lacy as a G.I. Eleanor meets in an airport bar.  The reason this is notable is that straight arrows like this are usually mocked but here he is given a certain nobility.  This film did lukewarm business on initial release but hopefully it will become a staple in holidays yet to come.

I wrapped up my holiday by seeing this movie for the second time last Sunday, the last day of the New Year weekend holiday. I enjoyed it even more the second time around. No, it's not a silly, campy romp like Jingle All The Way or Christmas With The Kranks. It's a movie for adults. But it also had a surprising amount of heart. Diane Keaton and John Goodman are in fine form as the matriarch and patriarch of a family assembling for Christmas. She wants one final big family Christmas before they break the news that they are breaking up. He doesn't feel good about hiding it from the grown kids, and neither really wants the break up, deep down. But the whole family has a lot to work through - secrets, disappointments, new beginnings, etc. The holidays do tend to bring out everything that's wrong with our lives into the wide open. and how the family comes together and works through all their issues is real, yet touching and endearing. It's a story of how the holidays can work a little magic in your life, if you let them. And as a bonus, it's all set to an absolutely killer soundtrack, including Bob Dylan, Sting, Alison Kraus and Robert Plant, a sweet Christmas standard sung by Keaton and Goodman, and a Nina Simone cover of one of my all time favorite songs ever recorded, the Bee Gees classic To Love Somebody. When this comes out on blu-ray, it's going into the collection, and will become a perennial favorite.

The Movie Review by Andy McKinney
Love the Coopers
  At this time of year we can expect to have an ensemble cast dramatic comedy involving the complications of modern family life at Christmas time.  This years entry to that category is "Love the Coopers" which has leaned more to the dramatic side, granted with some make you smile moments.
 The clan unites at the home of grandma and grandpa (Diane Keton and John Goodman), a couple married for over 40 years and whose commitment to and toleration for marriage has just about run out.  Ed Helms plays their son, a not successful but nice divorced father.  Marisa Tormei comes in as the younger sister of grandma.  Alan Arkin fills great grandpa's shoes, the ancient but still lucid elder of the clan who has a fascination with a very young waitress, Amanda Seyfried.  Olivia Wilde is another daughter, a free spirit.  All of them have fairly serious problems that we watch play out with various degrees of cringing or sympathy.
 Also note worthy are Anthony Mackie as a policeman working on Christmas Eve and Jake Lacy, a new to me actor who plays Joe, a solider on leave weather bound at the airport.  Lots of good actors gives a film a running start at excellence and this one has loads of very good actors.
 We have a look at two styles of sibling rivalry.  The first involves the brothers of the fourth generation, a 15ish jerk in the throws of adolescent angst and his adoring much younger brother.  The second and much more serious happens between the grandma (Keton) and her younger sister (Tormei), a decades long series of slights and misunderstandings.  These people, like all of us, are imperfect, flawed, often not entirely rational but always always with a capacity for great love.
 And that makes the movie for me.  In the tangled twine ball of the story we have four separate love stories going on.  The loutish teen summons up the juice to make a move on a girl teen of his desire.  This makes for an appallingly awkward and inept romance that will remind us all of that time in our own lives.  A tiny whisper of romance is just enough to round out and deepen the characters of the divorced dad (Helms) and the troubled young waitress (Seyfried).  Seyfried manages to wonderfully play her role with very little dialog, a tough job done well.  Keton and Goodman, the long married couple, depict the anguish of those who, after a lifetime together, may just be falling out of love.  But the best thing, the thing that makes the film for me is the relationship between the free spirit daughter (Wilde) and the chance met soldier (Lacy).  Wow, does that ever work.  Wilde, in her fourth film of 2015, is magical and enchanting.  Lacy plays the soldier with a laid back, mid west kind of calm decency that we know exists but we rarely see in a Hollywood film.  They are polar opposites who find the mutual attraction un-resistible.  They do try to resist, they just can't.  Wilde and Lacy make us believe in love at first sight with such ease that we say "of course".
 Director Jessie Nelson has a good record in making movies that tug at our heartstrings.  He has directed the heart-warmers "I am Sam", "Stepmom" and "The Story of Us".  He manages to tell all the stories in the film without either leaving anyone behind or getting them jumbled.  The script comes from the computer of Steven Rogers.  Rogers has the imagination to invent strong characters and the skill to bring them to the semblance of actual human life.  His past efforts in the same vain include "Stepmom" and "P.S. I Love You".
 The performance by Olivia Wilde pushed this one into the superior four saw blade range.  It runs for one hour and 47 minutes while carrying a mild PG-13 rating.  Made on a prudent $17 million budget (does that shock you?  A 17 million dollar budget called prudent?) it grossed around $23 million over the three day opening weekend.  It will do well financially as it should.  This would be a good date movie, even for married people.

Over the past decade, we've seen a recent phenomenon in film, where producers cast many big names in a clip film, that all comes together in the end. While this may work well with superheroes, it has yet to be successful in regards to comedy. That is why the film, Love The Coopers can be defined with one saying, too many cooks in the kitchen. This film features a large and impressive cast, and the previews looked terrific, but I assure you, Ed Helm's little girl calling him a dick, is just about the only truly funny moment in this film. The story here has a lot of different angles, and they do come together quite nicely, but this film is not what it was intended to be, as the last thing I would refer to it as is a hilarious holiday film. A lot of people are going to see this film because of it's cast, and from young Timothee Chalamet to veteran Alan Arkin, this cast is remarkable, however the story is not, in fact this whole film was fairly dull. I expect a lot from the cast, but even Hollywood's best and brightest can't make a film work when the writing just isn't there. I love the concept and I really wanted to like this film, but in the end it's just a big disappointment.
